newsitem.title: USA: Universal plans blitz for Jurassic Park sequel.
newsitem.headline: Universal plans blitz for Jurassic Park sequel.

text.p: Universal Studios, eager to cash in on the long-awaited sequel to "Jurassic Park", will announce Monday a series of licensing agreements and promotional deals with a number of leading companies.

The announcement, which coincides with the start of the annual New York International Toy Fair, is aimed at building interest in the Steven Spielberg film "The Lost World: Jurassic Park" and tapping into the rich merchandise market for everything from toy dinosaurs to children's T-Rex underwear.
Judging by the windfall generated by the first film, which sold more than $1 billion in merchandise worldwide, Universal officials are optimistic about the sequel.

"We are extremely excited about the program's strategic alliances," said Cynthia Cleveland, president of merchandising and licensing for Universal. "This comprehensive licensing programme and its unique new products will reinvigorate the already record breaking Jurassic Park franchise."

To make sure Universal hits all of its target audiences, the studio formed partnerships with fast-food giant Burger King, toy-maker Tyco Toys Inc. and a variety of clothing companies. It also signed deals with cereal giant General Mills Inc., Tropicana, owned by Universal's parent company Seagram Co. Ltd. and Eastman Kodak Co..
The studio even signed a licensing pact with German auto giant Mercedes- Benz to coincide with the launch of the carmaker's new sport utility vehicle later this year.

"Jurassic Park" is one of Hollywood's most successful movies, grossing more than $900 million at the box office and more than $1 billion in merchandise. The film, which used dazzling special effects to tell a story about what goes wrong when scientists try to bring dinosaurs back from extinction, triggered an instant demand for dinosaur products, clothing and books.
The sequel, directed by Spielberg, is scheduled for release on Memorial Day.
